facts.text: Messrs. Brijlal Manilal and Company is a bidi factory situated in Sagar. The 1st Appellant, Chintamanrao, is the Managing-Partner of the firm while the 2nd appellant, Kantilal, is its active Manager.

The Company manufactures bidis in two stages. First stage: Management enters into contract with independent contractors known as Sattedars for supply of bidis. Management supplies tobacco and sometimes bidi leaves to Sattedars. Sattedars get bidis manufactured in their small factories or by outsiders in their houses, collect them, deliver to factory where they are sorted and checked. Selected bidis packed in bundles of 10 and 25 and left in tandul. Rejected bidis rebundled and returned.
Management pays Sattedars the cost of manufacture after deducting cost of tobacco supplied.
Second stage: Exclusively by labourers employed in the factory - warming bidis, wrapping in tissue papers, labelling, bundling in Pudas, then marketed.

Sattedar is independent contractor undertaking to supply bidis directly or through coolies, by manufacturing in own factory or entrusting to third parties, at a price after delivery and approval. Sattedar or coolies neither work in factory nor subject to supervision/control of appellants.
Coolies or third parties employed and paid by Sattedars. They bring bidis to factory for delivery per contract.
Factory employs workers under direct control/supervision for second part of process.

On December 9, 1952, Inspector B.V. Desai visited factory at 5:30 p.m. Found: Pirbaksha s/o Amir, Abdul Sagir s/o Sk. Alam, Deviprasad s/o Uddam, Ramshankar s/o Mulchand, Gopal s/o Mulchand, Nirpat s/o Bhagirath, Rameband s/o Gyan, Gotiram s/o Lila, Basodi s/o Gulu.
Of the 9 persons: Deviprasad, Nirpat, Gotiram are Sattedars; rest are coolies employed by Sattedars.
Inspector found first seven sorting/packing bidis into bundles of 10/25; last two bringing bidis in jali for warming.
Facts admitted by some persons who gave evidence; they came to deliver bidis manufactured by them.

Chief Inspector filed complaint against appellants for violation of ss.62 and 63: failure to maintain register of adult workers with prescribed entries; allowing workers to work without beforehand entries of attendance.
Judge-Magistrate, Sagar, in Criminal Case No.146/1953 dated August 5, 1953: Held contravention, convicted under s.92, fine Rs.50 (1st appellant), Rs.25 (2nd).
Second Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, Criminal Appeal No.368/1953 dated March 8, 1954: Confirmed 2nd appellant both ss.62/63; set aside 1st appellant s.62 but confirmed s.63.
Nagpur High Court, Criminal Revision No.295/1954 dated September 16, 1954: Dismissed revision.
Names of 9 persons not entered in register; no notice of periods of work displayed; no beforehand entries.

legal_issues.text: Whether Sattedars and their coolies found working in the factory are 'workers' within the definition under s.2(l) of the Factories Act, 1948, so as to require compliance with ss.62 and 63.
Construction of provisions of ss.62, 63, 92 and definition of 'worker' under s.2(l), 'factory' under s.2(m), 'occupier' under s.2(n).

petitioner_arguments.text: Sattedar is independent contractor undertaking specific job without submitting to control; neither Sattedar nor his employee is 'worker' under s.2(l); no duty to comply with ss.62/63 re them.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(l) Factories Act; distinction between contractor and workman

respondent_arguments.text: Definition of 'worker' comprehensive enough to include all persons working in factory, whether employed by factory or not.

court_reasoning.text: Manager must maintain register of adult workers in factory (premises with specified workers carrying manufacturing process). No adult worker to work except per notice s.61 and register entries. Contravention by occupier/manager punishable s.92. Appellants contravened if 9 persons were workers.

'Worker' means person employed directly or through agency in manufacturing process etc. Employment involves employer-employee-contract of service with control/supervision. Sattedar not employed by management; independent contractor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction contractor vs workman: control test.

court_reasoning.text: Test from Dharangadhra: right of control over manner of work. Sattedars not under factory control; can manufacture anywhere; only deliver bidis.
Coolies employed by Sattedars on own account, no privity with management; not employed directly or through agency by management.
Scheme of Ch.VI (ss.51-63): regulates workers under direct supervision/control of management; impossible if includes independent contractors.
Distinguishes Nagpur HC cases: Provincial Govt v Robinson (no issue on employment by factory); State v Jiwabhai (overbroad view dissented).

holdings.text: Sattedars and coolies not 'workers' under s.2(l) as not employed by factory/management; independent contractors. No offence under ss.62/63/92.
Whether person is worker depends on contract terms; decision confined to facts (Sattedars independent contractors delivering bidis).

precedents_cited.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Test of control/supervision for employer-employee relation under similar 'workman' definition in Industrial Disputes Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Provincial Government, Central Provinces and Berar v. Robinson
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide definition of worker but no contention on whether employed by factory occupier.
Wide connotation to 'employed' under s.66(1)(b); dissented if means any activity without employment contract.
Accepted similar interpretation of s.2(l); held persons workers on facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Coggins & Griffith (Liverpool) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Test: authority to control manner of execution of act.

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of worker requires employment with control; ss.62/63 mandate register/notice for factory workers under management control; contravention punishable s.92.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; convictions and orders of lower courts set aside. Sattedars and coolies not workers under Act; no violation of ss.62/63.

key_quotes.text: 'Worker' means a person employed, directly or through any agency, whether for wages or not, in any manufacturing process... The concept of employment involves three ingredients: 1 employer 2 employee and 3 the contract of employment.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The principle which emerges... is that the prima facie test... is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only... what work... but also the manner in which he shall do his work.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We, therefore, hold that the Sattedars in this case were not employed by the management as workers but were only independent contractors.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Our decision is not intended to lay down a general proposition... depends upon the terms of the contract... confined to the facts of this case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
